name_origin.etymology: The name derives directly from the Ladino (Judeo-Spanish) word 'Quajado' or Spanish 'Cuajada'. It comes from the verb 'cuajar' (to coagulate, curdle, or set). While in modern Spain 'cuajada' refers to a dairy curd dessert, in Sephardic culinary terminology, it refers to a savory casserole where eggs are used as the binding agent to 'set' the vegetables (potatoes, spinach, or leeks). The presence of this name in a Djerban cookbook likely reflects the influence of the 'Grana' (Livornese/European Jewish community in Tunisia) or general Sephardic diaspora terminology, as the indigenous Tunisian Arabic term for this exact dish is 'Maaqouda'.
name_origin.meaning: That which is set/curdled/coagulated (referring to the eggs binding the dish)
name_origin.sources_notes: Linguistically confirmed via Spanish/Ladino roots. The shift from dairy-setting to egg-setting is a standard semantic shift in Sephardic cooking (e.g., 'Quajado de Prasa'). The Hebrew spelling קוז'אדה uses the 'zh' sound (zayin with geresh) to approximate the Ladino 'J' sound.

alternative_names.name: Quajado
alternative_names.notes: Standard spelling in Turkish/Rhodesli Sephardic communities.

alternative_names.name: Maaqouda
alternative_names.notes: The most common name for this potato-egg pie in Tunisia (literally 'the knotted/bound one').

alternative_names.name: Mina
alternative_names.notes: A similar Sephardic pie, though usually made with matzah layers (Mina de patata).

similar_dishes.name: Maaqouda / Maâkouda
similar_dishes.similarity: Identical ingredients (mashed potato, egg, parsley, turmeric).
similar_dishes.key_difference: In Morocco, Maaqouda are often small fried patties; in Tunisia, it is often a baked pie (Tagine Maaqouda) identical to Cujada.

similar_dishes.name: Tortilla de Patatas
similar_dishes.key_difference: Cooked in a skillet (flipped) rather than baked in an oven; uses sliced potatoes rather than mashed.

similar_dishes.name: Potato Kugel
similar_dishes.key_difference: Uses grated raw potatoes (denser texture) rather than cooked mashed potatoes; lacks the turmeric/cumin profile.

similar_dishes.name: Sfereeya
similar_dishes.key_difference: Sfereeya specifically incorporates chicken, whereas Cujada/Maaqouda is often vegetarian.
